description: Excel is more than just columns and rows of data. Excel can perform calculations from simple addition to complex formulas with its vast library of named functions. In this series, we cover everything you need to know about crunching numbers in Excel. There are multiple sections ranging from the very basics to more advanced data analysis to a reference guide of the different Excel functions by category. This series is for beginners as well as advanced users of Excel.

This series is for beginners as well as advanced users of Excel.
name: Excel Functions
subtitle: Excel functions are fun

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne start the Excel Functions series by laying down some foundational knowledge and terminology. Specific concepts/definitions discussed here include: formulas, functions, relative reference, absolute reference, and named ranges.
episodes.title: Introduction to Excel Function

episodes.description: While function syntax is the same in all platforms, there are a few nuances  using functions in Excel for Mac. In this episode, Vonne and Justin identify a few key differences in the Mac interface when inserting functions.
episodes.title: Functions in Mac

What if I hold Ctrl+Shift and
hit that quote?

327
00:18:32.968 --> 00:18:34.587
>> Yeah, no.

328
00:18:34.587 --> 00:18:35.876
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

329
00:18:35.876 --> 00:18:39.360
I was trying to figure out a way around
the system, but that looks like it might

330
00:18:39.360 --> 00:18:40.771
break a bunch of stuff.
>> Yeah,

331
00:18:40.771 --> 00:18:43.768
I don't think that you can find
a way to break this one, Justin.

332
00:18:43.768 --> 00:18:45.029
It is exactly like,

333
00:18:45.029 --> 00:18:49.718
I will only copy the value above the cell
that you are selected in as a value.

334
00:18:49.718 --> 00:18:51.578
That's it, done.

335
00:18:51.578 --> 00:18:56.452
But it has to be directly above it,
because if I'm like out here and

336
00:18:56.452 --> 00:19:00.032
then I did Ctrl+Shift quote,
it's like, no.

337
00:19:00.032 --> 00:19:01.693
I don't know what you're doing.

338
00:19:01.693 --> 00:19:04.280
And on a Mac, it is Control.

339
00:19:04.280 --> 00:19:05.790
It is not Command.

340
00:19:05.790 --> 00:19:08.740
It's not Cmd+Shift, it is Ctrl+Shift.

341
00:19:08.740 --> 00:19:10.960
So just keep that in mind.

342
00:19:10.960 --> 00:19:14.870
So all right,
you didn't break me there, Justin.

343
00:19:14.870 --> 00:19:17.840
Or at least Excel helped
me not break you there.

344
00:19:17.840 --> 00:19:20.526
Again, use case scenarios as
to why you wanna do this.

345
00:19:20.526 --> 00:19:25.600
And honestly, the last one I have is
just that if you wanted to make this

346
00:19:25.600 --> 00:19:31.362
particular formula bar a little bit
bigger, especially when you start getting

347
00:19:31.362 --> 00:19:36.618
into really long, complicated formulas,
you can do Ctrl+Shift+U.

348
00:19:36.618 --> 00:19:41.422
And do you see how it automatically
made the formula bar just a little bit

349
00:19:41.422 --> 00:19:43.918
bigger and wider so you can see more?

350
00:19:43.918 --> 00:19:45.899
And you do Ctrl+Shift+U.

351
00:19:45.899 --> 00:19:50.007
Again, on the Mac,
it is Control, not Command.

352
00:19:50.007 --> 00:19:52.620
And then it just goes ahead and
extends it out a little bit.

353
00:19:52.620 --> 00:19:55.850
So making the formula bar
just a little bit bigger.

354
00:19:55.850 --> 00:19:58.775
So again, just a few shortcuts for
you guys.

355
00:19:58.775 --> 00:19:59.963
I find them helpful.

356
00:19:59.963 --> 00:20:03.519
And I wanted to put them all in one place,
just in case when you go through

357
00:20:03.519 --> 00:20:06.544
everything and you maybe see me
do it one way in one episode and

358
00:20:06.544 --> 00:20:08.860
another way in another episode.

359
00:20:08.860 --> 00:20:12.270
That's why I went ahead and
put them all together, after I've done

360
00:20:12.270 --> 00:20:16.510
quite a few of them, and I learned how
to do the function keys on my Mac.

361
00:20:16.510 --> 00:20:19.000
Check out the functions in Mac episode.

362
00:20:19.000 --> 00:20:21.474
It's in your System Preferences.
>> All right, well, Vonne,

363
00:20:21.474 --> 00:20:24.064
I'll tell you what, you gave us
a bunch of keyboard shortcuts and

364
00:20:24.064 --> 00:20:27.287
you gave us a few other shortcuts that'll
just help increase our productivity.

365
00:20:27.287 --> 00:20:29.830
So we had a little added bonus there.

366
00:20:29.830 --> 00:20:31.197
So thank you so much for that.

367
00:20:31.197 --> 00:20:32.532
And thank you for joining us.

368
00:20:32.532 --> 00:20:34.860
These are going to be very helpful to you.

369
00:20:34.860 --> 00:20:37.075
But speaking of being helpful,
we're gonna go ahead and

370
00:20:37.075 --> 00:20:38.284
help ourselves on out of here.

371
00:20:38.284 --> 00:20:41.109
So signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

372
00:20:41.109 --> 00:20:41.857
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

373
00:20:41.857 --> 00:20:43.749
>> And we'll see you next time.

374
00:20:43.749 --> 00:20:49.244
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore working with named ranges in Excel functions and formulas. Here, they will show: how to create a named range, naming conventions, access the Name Manager, use the helper, create named ranges from a selection, delete named ranges, and use named ranges in formulas.
episodes.title: Named Ranges

>> It is, and we should move on to,

16

we're talking about named ranges.

17

Yes, so much fun with these, and what

We're gonna go ahead and demonstrate

But the whole idea is that you

>> Shortest episode ever.

Well, those C2 through C5,

>> Sales totals, or whatever,

26
00:01:23.746 --> 00:01:28.522
>> Yeah, those are my January sales,

And that way, you could use those named
ranges to be able to navigate to those

00:01:33.203 --> 00:01:36.582

those particular range of cells.

Or even better,

Okay, so

I just have a couple worksheets

00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:20.210

Now, we have actually covered

it's kinda sprinkled all in through there.

I believe we did it in the essentials,
actually, I can't even remember where

46

we've done it, I just know I've said

So this is where we're going to

Cool, now, I could go ahead if I wanted

Just normal, I could just go ahead and

So add up the south sales,
add up the north sales, we go ahead and

But the thing is,

00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:23.350

Now in our Excel environment,

Now this name box just goes ahead and

Since I'm in a range,

it's only gonna give me the first one

74
00:04:16.930 --> 00:04:20.600
Cuz if I click here or here,
notice that it deselects the range, but

75
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:22.850
then it goes ahead and
gives me that particular cell.

76
00:04:22.850 --> 00:04:28.770
So if I select these, it doesn't really

77
00:04:28.770 --> 00:04:30.300

78
00:04:30.300 --> 00:04:34.880
Well, how I can make this a named

00:04:34.880 --> 00:04:38.880
If I click on this, and notice I get

80

Now it goes ahead and highlights

00:04:46.700 --> 00:04:49.880
that's the cell reference within

83
00:04:49.880 --> 00:04:54.984
And I just start typing,

now the way that you

To make it sure that it knows that, yes,

87
00:05:06.444 --> 00:05:12.730

88
00:05:12.730 --> 00:05:16.500
And so now you can see that when I

89
00:05:16.500 --> 00:05:18.580

What would happen if,

>> I think nowadays,
it'll probably do it, here, let's try it.

94
00:05:33.020 --> 00:05:33.952
>> Yeah, let's give it a whirl.

00:05:33.952 --> 00:05:37.126
>> So let's go here and
if I go north_sales, whoops,

00:05:37.126 --> 00:05:40.155
let's move that cursor out,

00:05:40.155 --> 00:05:44.223
north_sales, and I hit the Tab,

98
00:05:44.223 --> 00:05:46.293
>> Okay.
>> Yeah, there you go, so no,

99
00:05:46.293 --> 00:05:47.930
it doesn't work with Tab.

100
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:50.373
>> Excellent.
>> Perfect, now you gotta go ahead and

101
00:05:50.373 --> 00:05:53.715
hit Enter, but
notice my flashing cursor's still there.

102
00:05:53.715 --> 00:05:55.534
>> It is.
>> If I click out of this and

103
00:05:55.534 --> 00:06:00.032
I select this again, it doesn't get it,
so that's what I'm saying.

104
00:06:00.032 --> 00:06:05.960
Emphasizing the, hit the Enter key, accept
the name, before you click off of it.

105
00:06:05.960 --> 00:06:10.285
Otherwise it's not gonna know that you
wanna go ahead and give it that name,

00:06:10.285 --> 00:06:12.124
so that's one of those things.

107
00:06:12.124 --> 00:06:14.632
So I'm gonna zoom out of here, and

00:06:14.632 --> 00:06:19.230
I don't know if you picked up that,

109
00:06:19.230 --> 00:06:22.520
Yep, yeah, cuz you know where we're going,
there's naming conventions.

110
00:06:22.520 --> 00:06:23.995
>> Yeah there are, there's always

111
00:06:23.995 --> 00:06:26.417
>> Yes, there's always rules for
these kinds of things,

112
00:06:26.417 --> 00:06:27.661
so syntax rules for naming.

113
00:06:27.661 --> 00:06:30.846
This is a link that I got off of,
it's in our show notes, so

114
00:06:30.846 --> 00:06:32.480

115
00:06:32.480 --> 00:06:35.908
And this is really just, here,

116
00:06:35.908 --> 00:06:37.872
defining these names in a formula.

117
00:06:37.872 --> 00:06:42.852
And so you can see that it gets to learn
about syntax rules for your names,

118
00:06:42.852 --> 00:06:46.720
so it has to,
first character must be a letter.

119
00:06:46.720 --> 00:06:49.000
And an underscore character or

120
00:06:49.000 --> 00:06:52.070
a backslash,
remaining characters if you can see.

121
00:06:52.070 --> 00:06:58.650
You cannot use the upper case and
lower case C and R as defined names.

122
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:03.873
Because they do use, and
we actually saw this in another

123
00:07:03.873 --> 00:07:08.776
series when we were linking

124
00:07:08.776 --> 00:07:13.760
And where it's giving me like an R and
a C, like row and column.

125
00:07:13.760 --> 00:07:18.700
Here, we're using A as a column and
2 as a row, but

126
00:07:18.700 --> 00:07:22.150
internally, it sees them as rows and
columns.

127
00:07:22.150 --> 00:07:26.140
So you can't say, this is going to be R25,

128
00:07:26.140 --> 00:07:30.133
that's not gonna, doesn't work that way.

129
00:07:30.133 --> 00:07:32.540
And so
you can see that spaces are not allowed,

130
00:07:32.540 --> 00:07:35.824
it can only be 255 characters,
well, that's a lot [LAUGH].

131
00:07:35.824 --> 00:07:38.977
>> Man, might as well just
give up at this point [LAUGH].

132
00:07:38.977 --> 00:07:41.205
>> The limitations [LAUGH].

133
00:07:41.205 --> 00:07:43.563
>> Yes, just tie my hands, why don't you?

134
00:07:43.563 --> 00:07:47.531
>> [LAUGH] And you can see that now, it
doesn't say that you can't use uppercase

135
00:07:47.531 --> 00:07:49.920
and lowercase, but it is case-sensitive.

136
00:07:49.920 --> 00:07:55.384
So if I named this, like for example over
here, remember I named this South_Sales.

137
00:07:55.384 --> 00:07:59.080
Well, if I'm going to use this
in a formula or go ahead and

138
00:07:59.080 --> 00:08:02.930
try to navigate to it by typing
in lowercase south_sales,

139
00:08:02.930 --> 00:08:08.380
It's not going to recognize it
because it does see case sensitivity.

140
00:08:08.380 --> 00:08:11.690
So that's something to know
about our naming conventions.

141
00:08:11.690 --> 00:08:14.280
Now I told you that one way we could
do this is go ahead and select it and

142
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:15.780

143
00:08:15.780 --> 00:08:18.530
But there is, of course,

144
00:08:18.530 --> 00:08:20.770
So if you come over here

145
00:08:20.770 --> 00:08:25.240
there's a whole group in our ribbon

146
00:08:25.240 --> 00:08:27.070
And we have, a name manager.

147
00:08:27.070 --> 00:08:28.070
And all these other things.

148
00:08:28.070 --> 00:08:30.893
Let's just take a look in the name
manager right now while we have just

149
00:08:30.893 --> 00:08:31.990
a small amount.

150
00:08:31.990 --> 00:08:35.515
So you can see that it says south
sales it gives me the values.

151
00:08:35.515 --> 00:08:40.581
It's giving where it's referred to you and
you can see that we've done this

152
00:08:40.581 --> 00:08:45.586
in our basics that we know that this is
a sheet name is called defined names.

153
00:08:45.586 --> 00:08:50.568
And that is absolutely
referencing B4 through B6, so

154
00:08:50.568 --> 00:08:57.460
we know where that particular place is or
what that named range is right here.

155
00:08:57.460 --> 00:08:59.880
So this is our name
manager that can be good.

156
00:08:59.880 --> 00:09:01.820
Now the thing is, with this name manager.

157
00:09:01.820 --> 00:09:03.011
Why don't we go ahead and

158
00:09:03.011 --> 00:09:06.033
do one thing in the name manager
while we're talking about it.

159
00:09:06.033 --> 00:09:10.593
Here, South Sales, what if I typed in $20,

160
00:09:10.593 --> 00:09:14.470
I added another cell within this range.

161
00:09:14.470 --> 00:09:19.980
But South Sales only refers to as
a named range for these three cells.

162
00:09:19.980 --> 00:09:23.770
What if I wanted to edit,
I don't wanna change the name.

163
00:09:23.770 --> 00:09:26.310
I need to add more of that reference.

164
00:09:26.310 --> 00:09:29.690
That's where that name manager can
come in handy, to where you can go in,

165
00:09:29.690 --> 00:09:30.910
let's go look at it.

166
00:09:30.910 --> 00:09:35.850
You can edit that particular name,
say all right, well let's go ahead and

167
00:09:35.850 --> 00:09:39.640
if I click it,
notice it says I could change the name.

168
00:09:39.640 --> 00:09:43.630
Maybe I wanted to do a lowercase
instead of uppercase just because.

169
00:09:43.630 --> 00:09:47.620
And then it refers to,
well I just need to change that reference.

170
00:09:47.620 --> 00:09:49.790
So I can click this
little button right here.

171
00:09:49.790 --> 00:09:51.050

531

533

534

This is simple,

you're the only guru we need.

00:29:37.520 --> 00:29:40.380

00:29:43.800 --> 00:29:45.930

554
00:29:45.930 --> 00:29:47.802
And thank you for watching OfficeProTV.

00:29:47.802 --> 00:29:49.790

00:29:49.790 --> 00:29:50.640

557
00:29:50.640 --> 00:29:51.488
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

558
00:29:51.488 --> 00:29:53.099
>> And we will see you again very soon.

episodes.description: Adding up numbers is one the most commonly used tasks in Excel. In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the SUM function, including shortcuts and tricks.
episodes.title: SUM

down on the computer is are they

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the SUMIF function. SUMIF adds a range of numbers based on single criteria.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the COUNTIF and COUNTIFS functions. These functions count the number of occurrences based on singular (COUNTIF) and multiple (COUNTIFS) criteria.
episodes.title: COUNTIF, COUNTIFS

episodes.description: The AVERAGE function is used to find the arithmetic mean of a range of numbers. In other words, add them up and divide by the number of items. The AVERAGEA is used to evaluate if text is present in the range.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the AVERAGEIF and AVERAGEIFS functions. These functions return the average of a group of numbers of based on singular (COUNTIF) and multiple (COUNTIFS) criteria.

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin explore functions that return the minimum (MIN) and maximum (MAX) values within a range. The SMALL function returns the smallest designated position within a range, for example, the 3rd smallest value. The LARGE returns the largest designated position. They also discuss the MINA and MAXA functions, which does not ignore text.
episodes.title: MIN, MAX, SMALL, LARGE

episodes.description: The RAND function returns a random number between 0 and 1 while the RANDBETWEEN allows a user to specify the range of the generated random number, for example, between 5 and 50.

episodes.description: The MONTH, DAY, and YEAR functions will return the month, day, and year from a date as a number. The TEXT function converts a number to text based on designated format codes. For example, TEXT can be used to convert 6 to June.

episodes.description: CONCAT and TEXTJOIN are two functions that join together (concatenates) text from cells. These functions require an Office 365 subscription and replace the CONCATENATE function.

episodes.description: TRIM is an easy way to clean up extra spaces in the beginning and ending of a string of text. The CLEAN function will remove nonprintable characters; however, it's not as straight forward as one might think.  Both functions can be used to clean up text imported from other applications or operating systems.
episodes.title: TRIM, CLEAN

episodes.description: The INDEX function returns a value based on the specified position of the value within a range. While the description of the function is not very straight forward, Vonne and Justin demonstrate how useful the function is for users. They also combine INDEX with MATCH to show how to create dynamic lookups.

episodes.description: One of the most popular functions, VLOOKUP finds a value in a range then returns another value in the same row based on the column number of the range. Vonne and Justin demonstrate with some basic examples and scenarios of when to use this function.

episodes.description: LOOKUP was the predecessor to the VLOOKUP and HLOOKUP functions. While not as flexible, the LOOKUP function does have some good use case scenarios. Vonne and Justin demonstrate some of those scenarios in this episode.
